subject: Data
title: The CAP Theorem: Pick Two of Three
description: A micro-lesson that makes The CAP Theorem: Pick Two of Three usable.

hook.text: A distributed database can be consistent, available, and partition-tolerant. But it can only guarantee two at once.

buildup.text: The CAP theorem, proved in 2002, states that network partitions force a choice between consistency and availability.

discovery.text: Banks choose consistency â€” better to reject a transaction than process it incorrectly during a network split.

twist.text: Social media chooses availability â€” showing a slightly stale feed is better than showing nothing at all.

climax.text: CAP theorem explains why different applications use different databases â€” there's no universal best choice.

punchline.text: You can't have it all. CAP theorem is database engineering's hardest truth.

quiz.question: What does the CAP theorem state about distributed databases?
options: They're always faster than single databases
They can only guarantee two of: consistency, availability, partition tolerance
